Differential privacy is a branch of theoretical computer science that aims to provide a method to maximize the accuracy of queries from statistical databases while minimizing the chances of identifying personal data. In effect, we develop a numerical measurement of privacy. By releasing summary statistics of databases in a differentially private manner, we preserve the privacy of each individual’s data while still providing valuable information needed to perform statistical regressions on the data. I optimized and implemented algorithms to release differentially private means and covariance matrices.
Part of Privacy Tools for Sharing Research Data: A National Science Foundation Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace Project

Developed a router for Synopsys. Invented the track assignment as an essential part between global and detailed routing. Invented an efficient rectilinear spanning tree algorithm. Invented an efficient rectilinear Steiner tree algorithm. Invented static timing analysis with crosstalk as a fixpoint on a complete lattice.

Invented a network flow based crosstalk minimization river routing algorithm. Invented a crosstalk-aware global routing with track assignment. Co-Invented an efficient wire-sizing algorithm. Invented the first exact gate decomposition algorithm for power minimization. Invented the first optimal algorithm for simultaneous routing and buffer insertion. Proved that retiming and re-synthesis is not complete for sequential equivalent circuits, which requests an operation called sweep to do more transformations. 10 years later, it is finally shown by me that retiming and re-synthesis with sweep can complete any sequential equivalent transformation. The result is based on Abardi and Lamport's demonstration that any two general equivalent systems must have a refinement mapping between their states. Co-invented a decision procedure based on BDD for equality theory with un-interpreted functions.
